contextId.information: "His mother, Mary, was going to marry Joseph." Parents normally arranged the marriages of their children. AT: "The parents of Mary, the mother of Jesus, had promised her in marriage to Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: His mother, Mary, was engaged to marry Joseph

contextId.information: Joseph had not married Mary yet, but when a man and woman promised to marry each other, Jews considered them husband and wife though they did not live together. AT: "Joseph, who was supposed to marry Mary" or "Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that the learned men told him when the star appeared. AT: "what time the star had appeared. The learned men told Herod when the star first appeared" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: what time the star had appeared

contextId.information: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "until I tell you it is safe to come back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that Joseph, Mary, and Jesus remained in Egypt. AT: "They remained" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Herod did not kill the children himself. AT: "He gave orders for his soldiers to kill all the boys" or "He sent soldiers there to kill all the boy babies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He sent and killed all the male children

contextId.information: These are the names of the tribes that lived in these areas before foreigners took control of the land of Israel many years earlier. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: in the territories of Zebulun and Naphtali

contextId.information: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "throwing a net into the water to catch fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: casting a net into the sea

contextId.information: At night when it is dark, people can see the city lights shining. This can be stated in active form. AT: "During the night, no one can hide the lights that shine from a city on a hill" or "Everyone sees the lights of a city on a hill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: A city set on a hill cannot be hidden

contextId.information: The phrase "all things" refers to everything in the law. AT: "everything in the law" or "all that is written in the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "the judgment" implies that a judge will condemn the person to die. AT: "A judge will condemn anyone who kills another person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Whoever kills will be in danger of the judgment

contextId.information: It seems here Jesus is not referring to a human judge but rather to God condemning the person who is angry with his brother. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: will be in danger of the judgment

contextId.information: It is implied that this is God's altar at the temple in Jerusalem. AT: "to God at the altar in the temple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that those who see the person will honor him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "in front of people just so that they can see you and give you honor for what you have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: before people to be seen by them

contextId.information: Jesus said "that day" knowing his hearers would understand he was referring to the day of judgment. You should include "the day of judgment" only if your readers would not understand otherwise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Jewish law required that the person show his healed skin to the priest, who would then allow him or her to return to the community, to be with other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The law of Moses required that someone healed of leprosy give a thanksgiving offering to the priest. When the priest accepted the gift, people would know that the man had been healed. Lepers were ostracized, banned from the community, until they had proof of their healing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: offer the gift that Moses commanded, for a testimony to them

contextId.information: Jesus' hearers would have thought that the Jews in Israel, who claim to be children of God, would have greater faith than anyone. Jesus is saying they are wrong and that the centurion's faith was greater. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I have not found anyone with such faith in Israel

contextId.information: Because Jews did not work or travel on the Sabbath, "evening" may imply after the Sabbath. They waited until evening to bring people to Jesus. You do not need to mention the Sabbath unless you need to avoid wrong meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that they wanted Jesus to heal them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of the statement can be made explicit. AT: "stay in that person's house until you leave the town or village" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
If necessary, you can make explicit how the disciple becomes like the teacher. AT: "know as much as his teacher knows" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

If necessary, you can make explicit how the servant becomes like the master. AT: "and the servant should be satisfied to become only as important as his master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: and the servant like his master

contextId.information: This means they sang sad songs like women did at funerals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is sacred bread that priests placed before God in the tabernacle. AT: "bread that the priest placed before God" or "the sacred bread" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here Jesus quotes scripture. AT: "The prophet Hosea wrote this long ago: 'I desire mercy and not sacrifice.' If you had understood what this meant, you would not have condemned the guiltless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: If you had known what this meant, 'I desire mercy and not sacrifice,' you would not have condemned the guiltless

contextId.information: They did not just want to accuse Jesus in front of the people. The Pharisees wanted Jesus to give an answer that contradicted the law of Moses so they could take him before a judge and legally charge him with breaking the law. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: so that they might accuse him of sinning

contextId.information: You can make explicit why they want to see a sign. AT: "to see a sign from you that proves what you say is true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: to see a sign from you

contextId.information: This request angers Jesus because of the religious leaders skeptical attitude about Jesus. He had already performed many miracles, but they still did not believe him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It will actually be God who condemns Jesus' generation. AT: "and God will listen to the citizens of Nineveh and condemn this generation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

You can make explicit the implicit meaning of Jesus' statement. AT: "than Jonah is here, yet you still have not repented, which is why God will condemn you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It will actually be God who condemns Jesus' generation. AT: "and God will listen to the citizens of Nineveh and condemn this generation." See how you translated a similar statement in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:12:41|12:41]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit the implicit meaning of Jesus' statement. AT: "than Solomon is here, yet you do not listen. That is why God will condemn you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that he sat down to teach the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that Jesus got into a boat because it would make it easier to teach the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: so he got into a boat

contextId.information: You can make explicit what the people will see. AT: "you will see what God does through the prophets, but you will not understand it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: while seeing you will see, but you will in no way perceive

contextId.information: You can make explicit what they have seen. AT: "the things you have seen me do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to seed that was sown or that fell. AT: "The seed that was sown" or "The seed that fell"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Mustard seeds were the smallest seeds known to the original hearers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: This seed is indeed the smallest of all other seeds

contextId.information: The implied information is that the yeast and the three measures of flour were made into dough for baking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: until all the dough had risen

contextId.information: The implied information is that the person buys the field to take possession of the hidden treasure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: sells everything he possesses, and buys that field

contextId.information: "his hometown." This refers to the town of Nazareth where Jesus grew up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Philip was still alive when Herod married Herodias. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit the implicit information. AT: "in the midst of the guests attending the birthday celebration" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"he left" or "he went away from the crowd." It is implied that Jesus' disciples went with him. AT: "Jesus and his disciples left" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This washing is not only to clean hands. This refers to a ceremonial washing according to the tradition of the elders. AT: "they do not wash their hands properly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: they do not wash their hands

contextId.information: It is implied that "his father" means "his parents." This means the religious leaders taught that a person does not need to show respect to his parents by taking care of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: does not need to honor his father

contextId.information: It is implied that Isaiah is speaking what God told him. AT: "when he told what God said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that the disciples went with Jesus. AT: "Jesus and his disciples went away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This phrase implies that she is requesting that Jesus heal her daughter. AT: "Have mercy and heal my daughter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The situation can be stated more clearly. AT: "If the sky is red in the evening" or "If the sky is red when the sun is setting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The situation can be stated more clearly. AT: "If the sky is red in the morning" or "If the sky is red when the sun is rising" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This request angers Jesus because of the religious leaders skeptical attitude about Jesus. He had already performed many miracles, but they still did not believe him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:12:38|12:39]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The name Peter means "rock." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The disciples are referring to the belief that Elijah will come back to life and return to the people of Israel before the Messiah comes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Why then do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?

contextId.information: It is implied that the man wants Jesus to heal his son. AT: "have mercy on my son and heal him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Fishermen tied hooks to the end of a line, then threw it in the water to catch fish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"treat him as you would treat a Gentile or tax collector." This implies that they should remove him from the community of believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: let him be to you as a Gentile and a tax collector

contextId.information: It is implied that Jesus means "if at least two of you" or "if two or more of you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"gave him over." Most likely the king himself did not take the first servant to the torturers. AT: "he ordered his servants to give him over" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the disciples were amazed." It is implied that they were astonished because they believed having riches was proof that God approved of someone. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

If necessary, you can make explicit why the ten disciples were angry. AT: "they were very angry with the two brothers because each of them wanted to sit in the places of honor next to Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: they were very angry with the two brothers

contextId.information: These are ways to show honor to Jesus as he was entering Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: crowd spread their cloaks on the road, and others cut branches from the trees and spread them in the road

contextId.information: Jesus did not enter the actual temple. He entered the courtyard around the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that they were angry because they did not believe Jesus was the Christ and they did not want other people praising him. AT: "they became very angry because people were praising him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that Jesus did not enter the actual temple. He entered the courtyard around the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

contextId.quote: My oxen and fattened calves have been killed

contextId.information: It is implied that the king's soldiers killed the murderers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The disciples of the Pharisees supported paying taxes only to Jewish authorities. The Herodians supported paying taxes to the Roman authorities. It is implied that the Pharisees believed that no matter what Jesus said, he would offend one of these groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
People did not pay taxes directly to Caesar but to one of his tax collectors. AT: "to pay the taxes that Caesar requires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that Jesus means that they are mistaken about what they think about the resurrection. AT: "You are mistaken about the resurrection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that no one asked him the kind of questions that were intended to make him say something wrong so the religious leaders could arrest him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

"tombs that someone has painted white." The Jews would paint tombs white so that people would easily see them and avoid touching them. Touching a tomb would make a person ceremonially unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that Jesus was not in the temple itself. He was in the courtyard around the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that enemy soldiers will tear down the stones. This can be stated in active form. AT: "when the enemy soldiers come, they will tear down every stone in these buildings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: not one stone will be left on another that will not be torn down

contextId.quote: from anyone who does not possess anything

contextId.information: It is implied that this is a man whom Jesus had healed from leprosy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that Jesus was not in the actual temple. He was in the courtyard around the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
By calling this blasphemy, it is implied that the high priest understood that Jesus was claiming to be equal with God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The Jewish leaders were planning how they could convince the Roman leaders to kill Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

contextId.quote: If you are the Son of God, come down from the cross

contextId.quote: that he had cut into the rock
